div.head: List of Ruskinʼs Published Poems, 1830–46, Compiled by John James Ruskin
div.p: In MS IV, long after Ruskin had abandoned his use of the notebook, his father took it up to compile a list of Ruskinʼs published poems. John James may have begun compiling the list in 1845 since its longest segment—written in ink, in his florid, old‐fashioned hand—presents a sequential record of poems published between 1830 and 1845 (pp. 20–31). This part of the list may have been prompted by John Jamesʼs complaint to W. H. Harrison on 1 July 1845 that the published poems were inconveniently dispersed among various annuals: “It is the scatterment of looking for a needle in the bundle of hay I dislike—I know not how to have him or where to find him” (quoted in Dearden, “Ruskinʼs Poems 1850,” 154).

Strangely, for this doting parent, John Jamesʼs list begins with an error: the first entry reads “on Skiddaw & Derwent Water / page 72 Spiritual Times / Feby 1830 age 11 years.” Hence, “On Skiddaw and Derwent Water” became established as Ruskinʼs first known publication, and it was as recently as 1994 that James S. Dearden discovered Ruskinʼs actual debut in print, which occurred, not in the February 1830 issue of the Spiritual Times, but in the August 1829, with the forgotten “Lines Written at the Lakes in Cumberland.” (In the MS IV list, John Jamesʼs entry is scored through in pencil, which, if by him, perhaps indicates that he recognized the mistake. If so, he did not correct the entry.)

Following this first long segment of the list, on three following pages (p. 32, plus an unnumbered leaf), John James switched to pencil to record publications of 1846, along with some poems of earlier years, which he had omitted from the first segment. This year was the last in which Ruskin published poetry prior to the collecting of his verse in Poems (1850), with the exception of “Mont Blanc Revisited” published in late 1849 (see Ruskin, Works, 38:7) He mentions here the “Bundle Sheets w F. O.,” likely referring to bound proofs of Ruskinʼs contributions to Friendshipʼs Offering that W. H. Harrison had presented to John James, and that the doting father carried on his travels (see Ruskin, Works, 2:xxxiv; Dearden, “Ruskinʼs Poems 1850,” 154). This second stage of the list probably represents John Jamesʼs initial preparations for Poems (1850), a project first confided to Harrison in 1847 (Dearden, “Ruskinʼs Poems 1850,” 155). Published poems omitted from this list do not appear in Poems (1850).

The list reads as follows, with my interpolations set in square brackets. As already remarked in the Introduction, this first attempt at bibliography of Ruskinʼs early writings already committed a significant error, the incomplete publication information for no. 44:
[p. 20][In ink but crossed out in pencil:] on Skiddaw & Derwent Water / page 72 Spiritual Times / Feby 1830, age 11 years. [See no. 44 regarding John Jamesʼs omission of an earlier publication of part of this poem.]
[p. 21] The Months [no. 194] in Friendships offering of 1836 / page 290. [John James omitted Fragments from a Metrical Journal (originally part of no. 180) and no. 207—both published in Friendshipʼs Offering of 1835.]
[p. 22] The Last Smile [no. 222] page 102 / Friendships offering 1837 / Leoni a Legend of Italy [no. 212] / Friendship offering 1837 / page 217.
[p. 23] Friendship offering 1838 / Scythian Grave [no. 253] Page 110 / Remembrance [no. 249] page 119 / Christ Church [no. 252] page 287.
[p. 24] 1839 / Recreant [no. 260] page 56 in Amaranth / Wreck [no. 261] page 90 In London Monthly Miscellany / We care not what skies are the clearest [no. 262] page 48b[] / Though thou hast not a feeling for one [no. 263] page 491. / Iter ad Brundusium [no. 264] page 500 / Memory [no. 240] page 53b / The Name [no. 266] page 558 / Canzonet [no. 267] page 604 / meteorological journal [no. 268] pg 624 / Canzonet [no. 269] page 635 / Mirror [no. 250] page 653 / Song of Tyrolese [no. 271] page 739.
[p. 25] Friendships offering 1839 / Scythian Banquet Song [no. 259] page 25 / Aristodemus at Platea [no. 257] page 140.
[p. 26] Friendships offering / 1840 / Scythian Guest page 52 / Broken Chain page 137 part 1 & 2 [John Jamesʼs query; see no. 245a].
[p. 27] Friendships offering 1841 / Tears of Psammenitus page 37 / Two paths page 73 / Old Water Wheel page 107 / Farewell page 108 / Departed Light 217 / Agonia 288 / Broken chain 311 part 3 [John Jamesʼs query] / [in pencil] To -------- quese. [The last entry likely refers to To Ad√®le, which Cook and Wedderburn ascribe to the previous yearʼs volume of Friendshipʼs Offering, and which they say was entitled in that 1840 volume as To * * * (Works 2:110; 38:5); John Jamesʼs version of the title would refer to Ad√®leʼs marriage to Baron Duquesne.]
[p. 28] Friendships offering 1842 / Last Song of Arion page 48 / Hills of Carrara page 178 / Broken Chain part 4 page 359.
[p. 29] Friendships offering 1843 / Broken chain last part / Modern Painters.
[p. 30] Friendships offering 1844 / Battle of montenotte / Walk in Chamouni.
[p. 31] Book of Beauty 1845 / Madonna dell aqua 18 / Keepsake old seaman 653 / Alps 270.
[p. 32][From here, the list is written entirely in pencil:] 1846 / Keepsake / Arve at Cluse 234 / Mont Blanc 35 / Book of Beauty / Written among the Basses Alpes page 109 / Glacier 110.
[p. 33][blank verso] [on immediately following unnumbered recto] Gipsies St Helena 1837 / St Helena 1838 / Salsette 1839 / Bundle Sheets w F. O. [on immediately following unnumbered verso] compared with / Goethe / Coleridge / I. Taylor / Burke / Juvenal.
For Ruskinʼs response to this list, see Red Books.
